summary: This document is an FBI/DOJ news brief dated August 27, 2021, covering multiple national security and terrorism-related topics. It includes the announcement of the closure of the Metropolitan Correctional Center where Jeffrey Epstein died, updates on the T-Mobile hack, lawsuits related to the January 6 Capitol riot, and extensive coverage of the Afghanistan withdrawal, the Kabul airport attack, and various extremist groups.

events.title: Justice Dept. Announces Closure of MCC Jail
events.description: The Justice Department announces the closure of the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) in New York, the troubled jail where Jeffrey Epstein died. The 233 people held there will be moved.

events.title: Capitol Police Officers Sue Trump and Extremist Groups
events.description: A group of seven U.S. Capitol Police officers file a lawsuit against former President Trump, the Proud Boys, the Oath Keepers, Roger Stone, and others over the January 6 Capitol riot.

events.title: Sirhan Sirhan Parole Hearing
events.description: Sirhan Sirhan faces his 16th parole hearing for the 1968 assassination of Robert F. Kennedy. For the first time, no prosecutor argues to keep him imprisoned.

events.title: Kabul Airport Suicide Bombing
events.description: A complex attack involving two ISIS-K suicide bombers near Kabul airport's Abbey Gate and Baron Hotel kills at least 13 U.S. service members and many Afghans.

events.title: IRA Assassination of Lord Mountbatten
events.description: The Irish Republican Army (IRA) detonates a bomb on Lord Louis Mountbatten's fishing vessel, killing him, his grandson, and two others off the coast of Ireland.

keyFacts: The U.S. Justice Department announced the closure of the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) in New York, the jail where Jeffrey Epstein died in 2019.
Capitol Police officers sued former President Trump, the Proud Boys, Oath Keepers, and Roger Stone, alleging a conspiracy to use violence to stop the certification of the 2020 election.
The document contains extensive real-time coverage of the August 26, 2021, suicide bombing at Kabul airport claimed by ISIS-K, which killed 13 U.S. troops and many Afghans.
It reports that U.S. officials in Kabul provided the Taliban with a list of names of American citizens, green card holders, and Afghan allies to facilitate evacuation, a move that caused outrage.
The brief includes a historical note on the August 27, 1979, IRA assassination of Lord Louis Mountbatten, marking its anniversary.
